Award.AwardTitle: Expanding Deep-sea Horizons: Scientific Priorities in Abyssal Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI) will host a series of three online workshops and one in person workshop to identify key science priorities at abyssal depths and verification needs when Alvin comes out of overhaul. The online meetings will be preceded by a widely distributed survey to determine the research community's opinions on the key areas that remain under investigated in the abyss and on what new and current instrumentation is needed to investigate the deep ocean.

The online meetings will be tentatively organized around three themes: abyssal operations, trenches and transform faults, and abyssal plains and seamounts. An in-person meeting will bring together deep-sea researchers from all major disciplines and at different career stages to synthesize the online meetings into two manuscripts, one that reviews state of research in the abyss and defines the community consensus on research priorities and a second that provides guidance to DeSSC, NSF, and NDSF in planning a science verification expedition when the 6500mrated HOV Alvin comes out of overhaul in 2021.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported a community workshop to determine consensus views on scientific priorities for research at abyssal depths in the ocean (4000-6500m) in the coming decade. The human-occupied submersible Alvin will soon complete its overhaul and upgrade that will enable it to dive to 6500m, significantly expanding access to abyssal depths for the US research community. The workshop brought together biologists, chemists, geologists, engineers, students, post-docs, media members, and policy makers for trans-disciplinary discussions. 

The workshops were held virtually and arranged into four topic areas that were guided by a community survey. The topics included:  Abyssal Plains & Seamounts; Trenches & Transforms; Technology & Societal Relevance; and Diversity-Equity-and-Inclusion. Prior to each workshop, presentations by four subject-matter experts were posted to the conference website. Participants viewed the presentations prior to each meeting so that time could be devoted to small-group discussion. Presentation recordings and discussion notes are archived on the workshop website (ndsf.whoi.edu/alvin/workshop-alvin-in-the-abyss/). 

There was broad agreement among the workshop participants that our baseline knowledge of the abyssal region of the oceans is limited. As a result, there was a recommendation from the community for greater coordination amongst abyssal science projects so that community samples and observations (outside of the central discipline of a study) might be collected. This recommendation will be further developed during the upcoming Alvin Science Verification expedition through the documentation of sampling protocols for abyssal research. 
The community recognized that many of the key science questions for abyssal research are unique (or nearly so) to abyssal depth ranges. These include petit spot volcanism, organismal adaptation to high pressures and low energy, and ultra-high temperature hydrothermal venting. In addition, it was recognized that other science questions have key links to other depth ranges in the ocean; for example, larval dispersal from physically isolated deeps, transport of carbon-rich sediment from continental slopes into trenches, and rates of carbon transport from the upper ocean to abyssal plains.

The community also identified technological developments necessary for effective abyssal research. These included modification of existing sampling devices for higher pressure (e.g., gas-tight fluid samplers); minituarization of samplers and devices so more samples could be collected, development of in-situ sensors to guide sampling, and development of autonomous systems that can extend the range of sampling either horizontally or vertically relative to traditional and depth-limited submersibles.

The workshop also included discussions of diversity, equity, and inclusion in deep sea science and recognized that our community needs new approaches to addressing our lack of diversity. Discussions were focused on what approaches (local, insititutional, or community-wide) have been successful. A key recommendation was the need to ensure the research ship environment is welcoming to all. As a result, the upcoming Alvin Science Verification Expedition will adopt a pre-cruise prospectus that provides information to new researchers and sets expectations for creating an inclusive environment. In addition, the value of telepresence was identified for enhancing inclusivity, especially for researchers with disabilities, care-giving obligations, or where cultural norms prevent participation.

The results of the workshop are currently being synthesized in a manuscript for publication and have guided the development of the upcoming Alvin Science Verification Expedition.
